title: Paris' Notre Dame structural difficulties, uncertainty over rebuilding complicate rebuilding effort
text:
Six months after the April 15 fire that tore through the 13th-century Notre Dame de Paris cathedral's roof and toppled its spire, the reconstruction process is shaping up to be much more complex than many anticipated.

Workers have had to clean up significant quantities of lead that melted from the roof and contaminated areas around the cathedral, with critics saying the authorities were slow to warn the public of the associated risks.

The top priority is to eliminate any risk to the vaulted ceiling, with the main danger coming from 500 tonnes of scaffolding that was erected around the fire for renovation work before the blaze.

The damage caused by just a single bar of scaffolding falling could prove irreparable, and the work to remove the structure will take several months.

'This is not scare-mongering. It is a physical reality,' said Christophe-Charles Rousselot, director general of the Fondation Notre-Dame, the charity that is overseeing the gathering of donations to the cathedral told AFP.

Reconstruction work underway at Notre Dame de Paris Cathedral. The April fire destroyed the landmark's roof and raised concerns about melted lead in the surrounding area.

Above all, the process of securing an edifice still at risk of collapse after the fire damage has taken precedence over any reconstruction.

French President Emanuel Macron' five-year goal would see the cathedral's reconstruction completed in the spring of 2024, before Paris hosts the Summer Olympic Games that year.

'We will rebuild the cathedral even more beautifully and I want it to be finished within five years,' Macron said on national television on the evening of April 16, 2019 – one day after the fire destroyed the cathedral.

'And we can do it,' he added.

There is no consensus, however, on how the cathedral should look after reconstruction. Many experts want a newly rebuilt spire to be exactly like the original, whilst French President Emanuel Macron is arguing for an innovative solution.

But many see the spire, a late addition to the mediaeval cathedral designed by the 19th-century French architect Eugene Viollet-le-Duc, as an integral part of the building.

'It needs to be rebuilt as it was before,' opined Philippe Villeneuve, the architect in charge of restoring the cathedral, arguing that the sheer power of the spire integrated it with the mediaeval church.

Villeneuve's opinion is backed by the descendants of Eugène Emmanuel Viollet-le-Duc, the French architect who designed the spire.

The French public concur, opinion polls indicate.

The government has also not ruled out the possibility of an international competition for architects to design something new.

It is only at the end of 2020 that a complete check will allow architects to work out how to restore the cathedral. No reconstruction is expected to start before 2021.

Notre Dame suffered a major fire in April 2019, though Emanuel Macron said that he wants the rebuilding work completed by 2024.

Experts are also intensively researching the precise original architecture of the cathedral, so that when reconstruction begins it is as accurate as possible.

'Before 2010, we only have old-style surveys, plans that have been redrawn on numerous occasions which are very partial and very imprecise,' said Remi Fromont, one of the architects responsible for the site who is working on drawing up accurate plans.

Andrew Tallon, a Belgium-born scholar who died aged 49 in November 2018, carried out hugely valuable laser scans of the interior in 2010 that have proved an even more valuable legacy than he could have imagined.

'We know that we will have shortcomings. Not all the chapels were systematically scanned. There are still areas of doubt,' Fromont said.

Price tag for the work is also an issue, and it is impossible at this stage to say 'how much this is going to cost, how long this is going to last,' said Michel Aupetit, the archbishop of Paris.

Private individuals and, above all, rich French co-operations rushed to pledge hundreds of millions for the cathedral's reconstruction.

There were concerns whether this funding would ever be realised.

But France's richest man Bernard Arnault in September signed a formal accord over his pledge for £180 million ($220 million), as did the Pinault family for their promised £90 million ($110 million).

A signing on another £90 million ($99.2 million) promised by the oil giant Total is expected in October.

The consortium of fundraising groups behind the drive believes that £720 million ($881 million) can be raised in total, with over £554 million ($678 million) now either transferred or pledged.

Lovers of the historic masterpiece, be they tourists, architecture buffs or worshippers, may have to wait some time before Notre-Dame becomes theirs again.

'I have felt myself orphaned, it is like being in mourning,' said Michele Chevalier, 70, a regular at Notre-Dame who was at the service when the first evacuation took place.

'I still manage to pray, but it's not the same.'
description: Paris's Notre Dame cathedral is facing a number of current and future difficulties in plans to rebuild the French capital's landmark
